column1: Will Kassym-Jomart Tokayev either flee Kazakhstan or cease to be its president before 7 July 2022?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Unlikely at the beginning, why my "5%", now propped up by Putin who cannot afford to lose him without a ready crony.
After the Saint-Petersburg economic forum held last week it became apparent that Tokayev has China's backing and can allow himself to defy Russia without political consequences.
Seems to have got a grip on the situation. Little risk in the next few weeks of any upheaval, but not no risk, hence 1%.
it seems Tokayev has taken a firm grip on the nation.
Referendum for constitutional changes (including diminishing the presidential powers) successful with overwhelming approval:
Adjusting for time and forecasting that probability is <1% from here on.
I'm lowering the probability that he will cease to be Kazakhstan's president because of the approaching deadline.

Though the sentiment of the crowd is that Tokayev is unlikely to step-down or flee before Jul 7,2022, I feel that the reason for protests seems fundamental enough (gas prices) that things could turn on a dime for any of the current leaders.
Down 2% for passage of time.
Rounding down to 0
There is a non-zero chance he will cease breathing before that date.

I read recently that Tokayev has implemented reforms on government that appear to improve the democratization of the country. I think this is likely to help him consolidate support with former protestors. lowering my estimated probability.
The situation in Kazakhstan looks like its stabilizing.
https://astanatimes.com/2022/03/president-tokayev-signs-nationwide-action-plan-to-implement-announced-political-reforms/
Not much news on the political situation in Kazahkstan. I would assume no news is good news for Tokayev.
Down 3% for passage of time.
https://thediplomat.com/2022/03/tokayev-outlines-new-kazakhstan-in-state-of-the-nation-address/
Maintaining my response, I think Kazakhstan is in a difficult spot at the moment

Endogenous change: In country detractors would have to regroup fast to meet July deadline and reasons for popular discontent would need to accelerate fast for this proposition to be realised. If he hedges his bets on Ukraine ("let's not rile R, look what's happened to those who do" balanced with "let's not condemn R (because I quite like my job)" he should be fine. Exogenous change: Russia is most influential and seems to back current leader, but could conceivably look to swap him out if he is luke warm on Russia's war against Ukraine, or simply to demonstrate that they can. This exogenous risk may be the bigger risk to him, rather than endogenous change?

The state of the Russian economy also reflects on KZ. I may be wrong but the KZ tenge is either tied to the ruble or is very interconnected. There was also recently a panic over a perceived shortage of sugar. If riots break out again, Russia may not rush to Tokayev’s aid this time: (1) They’re busy elsewhere, (2) Tokayev keeps an independent line from RU on Ukraine, DNR, LNR. But I think the timeline for mobilization is now too short. Opposition forces may need more time to regroup after recent purges. I would have a higher estimate if the ifp were extended to next Jan. There’s bound to be economic fallout, at least temporarily.

I slightly increase my estimate, because Putin won't be able to send troops in case if needed. But to be honest, as long Tokayev keeps a distance from Putin like the rest of the world and not getting involved into Ukraine, he should be fine. https://thediplomat.com/2022/03/kazakh-russian-relations-in-the-context-of-the-war-in-ukraine/
Only if Putin falls . . .
Weakening of Putin's Regime might also weaken Tokayev, who used Russian support for his "palace coup".

Though the quelling of protests was effective in early January, Russia is otherwise unable to assist with the current protests as over half of active-duty ground forces are engaged in the Ukrainian theater.

Though Russia is currently distracted elsewhere currently, the January stomp-down seems to have severely weakened Tokayev's detractors, making them less able to take advantage of the current opportunity.

Russian troops are distracted with the war in Ukraine, removing a potential prop for Tokayev's regime. Food and fuel prices likely to rise, Chinese investment not likely to be forthcoming to support the Kazakh economy. Protests continuing in many Kazakh cities. https://eurasianet.org/kazakhstan-no-end-in-sight-for-protests-in-western-region
Absence of support for Ukraine invasion unhelpful, but still suspect Putin has hands full and would not be so rash as to further complicate situations on his borders.

Raising on this (although I couldn’t verify the info yet—nothing on Tengrinews): “ 🇷🇺🇰🇿⚡NBC News says Kazakhstan turned down a Russian request to join the war.” https://t.me/OSINTUkraine/798 Still, July may be too soon even if Tokayev does anger Putin.
Russian intervention in Ukraine pushing me to almost zero chance of this, unless of course, he speaks out in defense of Ukraine.
Thus far the situation remains stable and no further developments have occurred. Only dramatic shocks in commodity markets could change the situation.

Amidst the turmoil in Kazakhstan, Tokayev shared in January that he would not be fleeing the country and would take over as the head of the Security Council. The unrest being experienced in the nation is something Tokayev shared that he would use harsher measures to subdue. Due to this, it seems unlikely that he will end up fleeing. The more likely option is that he will end up addressing, or attempting to address, the unrest.
Situation seems to be in similar state

There don't appear to be any significant updates to this situation within the past week. I think it's possible that should future unrest arise, the CSTO may be less inclined to intervene (not sure of the legal obligations of treaty members) given that the Russians have their hands full situation in the Ukraine. In any case, there is not necessarily any reason to believe that demonstrations will be revived. Slight upward revision of the probability of Tokayev fleeing in light of the Russia-Ukraine situation.
Only if Putin wants him gone. . .
Some of us remember how many people on GJO were convinced that Assad would be out by March 2016.

There are 4.5 months (137 days) until the close of the question. Tokayev was elected to a five-year team, and thus is not scheduled to leave office until after the close of the question. Thus, cease to be president is by 1) death (I rate as <1%), 2) quitting (I rate as less than 1%), or 3) by legal/illegal means (also <1%). For item 3), Tokayev has acknowledged problems such as poverty and inequality of wealth distribution that would seem to address societal issues. He also plans a speech in March to announces reforms. This is a least a temporary means of relieving societal pressure on himself/his administration (https://astanatimes.com/2022/02/president-tokayev-to-deliver-address-to-nation-in-march-announce-political-reforms/ )

+5% on last week as recent revelations about Nursultan's corruption could open up fresh wounds + the internet crackdown https://www.thebureauinvestigates.com/stories/2022-02-17/kazakh-ex-dictator-used-uk-company-to-help-protect-8-billion-business-empire
Once more the situation remains relatively stable within the country.
It doesn't seem like there are any recent developments that threaten Tokayev's rule. Keeping my prediction where it is for the moment.
Kassym has recently confirmed his support from Putin, seems to be entrenching himself
He has the support of both Russia and China,the 'retired' fomer leader and members of the family who did not participate in the recent undertakings.

Kassym-Jomart seems to be increasing his autocratic behavior towards his opponents and critics, inclusion the media. He is increasingly confident and will probably have the support of China in the next few months.
He has materially strengthened his power and there is a broad consensus among elites around him. Population will be cautious about new protests now.
Time is running and I not see a clear sign of Kassym-Jomart Tokayev ceasing power

As of right now, the larger-scale unrest was put down. However, I don't think there is a zero-percent chance of President Tokayev leaving office, on account of grievances over low salaries remain. It's worth noting the possibility of Russian troops returning if tension over this issue escalates again, so chances of this happening remain low, but not impossible.
Kazakhstan is solidly authoritarian with Tokayev solidifying power.
After the Collective Security Treaty Organization operation the situation has calmed down an the authorities are once more secure in power.

New friendly meetings in China and seeming Russian support for Tokayev makes me think he's all but a shoe-in to remain president until at least 7 July 2022. I've adjust from 3% down to 1%. The 1% is because there is always a chance that another protest/riot/possible coup attempt could topple Tokayev but I see this as extremely unlikely in the timeframe of this question at this point.
Pressure seems to have abated a bit, so I am lowering my percentage forecast to 5%. Spring will bring more clarity.
Few updates from Kazakhstan make it seem like Tokayev will stay, but July is a long time away.
Very few updates on the situation to be found in the news lately. Seems likely that Tokayev stays in the absence of some other tumult that threatens his position.

Tokayev met with Xi at the Olympics-https://t.me/tengrinews/9210. And the Nazarbayevs keep losing their hold on KZ, the latest development being KZ Railroad terminating their contract with Nazarbayev’s daughter’s company. All this bodes well for the Tokayev regime for now.
Down 5% for passage of time.

Have not seen an update on Kazahkstan, which would appear to indicate that things have settled down. Barring another event like the protests, the likelihood Tokayev is forced to flee is likely very low.
no major Kazakhstan news in weeks

No recent changes in the situation mean no changes on my projection. Still seems unlikely but possible. We'll see what happens in the spring as temperatures warm people may be more inclined to political action.

I don't have a precise baseline number, but suspect the number of presidents or similar leaders who have fled is very low (<1%). He could die or quit, but neither is very likely either. He is consolidating power and will continue to be supported by Russia, so breaking away from the baseline isn't going to happen. The probability remains di minimus, so I'll call it 1% for now.

Recent reports have suggested that the President has rejected international probes into the military crisis that occurred in Kazakhstan, which claimed the lives of over 200 people and saw the intervention of Russian troops. Further articles have suggested that the President plans to complete "no more than two terms" though has also completely ruled out any possibility of terminating the position earlier. As is commonplace amongst many authoritarian regimes, it is a rarity in which the President is forced to flee the country unless a power grip is loosened and there is an imminent threat towards their security. Dictators such as Bashar al-Asad have survived through a brutal civil war and ongoing threats by rebel groups - meanwhile have managed to maintain power for an extensive period of time. Unless more precarious incidents are to unfold in the future, I do not foresee a likely scenario in which the President of Kazakhstan is forced to flee.
I bump upward because I don't know for sure whether there could be some kind of event that spurs another riot(s) that would push the leader back into a corner.

Making another forecast about Kazahkstan's fate in the near future. The short answer: Tokayev not being president at 7 July 2022 is in my estimate 1,5%. The reason why I lowered my estimation compared to my last forecast is that I came across this podcast with Joanna Lillis, who is a journalist residing for many years in the country and explains very well the current developments in Kazahkstan.
this flare up between two ALLIANCE MEMBERS ON Tajik BORDER THROWS A MONKEY WRENCH IN MY FIGURING.

Reducing probability on recent stability, no signs of renewed protests, departure of Russian troops, other minor news suggesting that Tokayev is keeping a firm grip on his leadership position, such as his recent election to head of the government party (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/1/28/kazakh-president-becomes-party-chair-after-sidelining-nazarbayev).
Tajikistan is moving army units and armored vehicles to the border with Kyrgyzstan amid escalation https://twitter.com/theragex/status/1486781599765127175
Given the instability in the region, anything is possible.
Distractions in Ukraine may open opportunities for other forces to take advantage and oust Kassym-Jomart
Rolling blackouts not a good sign, but social unrest not at its high point

The situation in Kazakhstan appears to have been stabilized after the deployment of CSTO forces. The underlying issues with the country's economy are unresolved but it's not clear that those issues were the only factor in inciting violent protests. A potential rift between Tokayev and his predecessor's supporters appears to have been repaired as Nursultan's nephew has retained a position in government he was expected to be removed from in the wake of the protests. All of this indicates that Tokayev, with the help of the CSTO, has consolidated power, and thus the likelihood that he is forced to flee in the near future seems to be diminished.

Tokayev seems to have consolidated power further after arresting thousands of protesters, support from Moscow, and a public appearance from former president Nazarbaev expressing support for Tokayev. I am lowering my probability from 6% to 5% and will continue to lower the number as the date approaches if these factors remain constant.
It seems that he has potentially strengthened his position relative to before the unrest so probably not going to happen but to be honest I don't know much at all about the politics of Kazakhstan.

I don't know how much stock to put in the Astana Times, but I think they can speak to the presence or lack of alarm. Tokayev ended the state of emergency 4 days ago. "Counter-terrorism" efforts continue, and it seems with the more lax security posture, Tokayev isn't too worried. https://astanatimes.com/2022/01/kazakhstan-ends-state-of-emergency-counter-terrorist-operation-continues/ https://astanatimes.com/2022/01/investigation-ongoing-police-officers-capture-more-illegal-weapons-after-mass-riots-video/

The recent protests were sparked by Tokayev lifting a cap on gas prices. He has replaced the cap for another 6 months. He faced mass street protests and fired his cabinet, but received military support from Russia which is likely to be maintained for at least the next 6 months. He faces no organised opposition. He was only elected in 2019, and is only 68 years old. It is unlikely that in the next 6 months he will be forced to leave the country. The most likely reason for him to be forced from power would be a coup from inside his own government, which would require Russian support, so the possibility of him fleeing is not zero.
Interestingly, not too dissimilar a question to the Bojo one…
Dictators never quit. Russia is backing him.

Tokayev is proceeding with removal of Nazarbayev’s people from key official posts. Nazarbayev recently recorded a message saying he is and has been in the capital and that there’s no conflict among the elite. His hands suggest he’s nervous. https://t.me/tengrinews/9011

Updating the forecast due to the fact that Nazarbayev is alive and was forced to go through a process of ritual self-humiliation referring to himself in a video call as a pensioner, and confirming his trust in Tokayev

This is a scary time for the world. Autocrats are rising in many areas, often supported by the people, but when not supported by the people, they are rising through oppressive means. America has lost its standing as a model Democracy and by international evaluations, falls somewhere between Oligarchy and Kleptocracy so it is no longer able to use its position to encourage democracies and to slow or hinder Autocracies.
Down to zero.

The impetus for the whole unrest were gas prices. I've only focused on the muscle of Russia mostly. But price controls are back in effect for 180 days; past the end of this question. Once people get reacclimated to paying for cheap gas, along with having Russia (and her troops) as a neighbor, the likelihood of Tokayev fleeing gets even lower. https://112.international/politics/government-of-kazakhstan-decides-to-limit-prices-for-fuel-food-communal-services-68373.html

Kazakhstan is a relatively stable country and protests have been relatively contained with Russian help. I do not see major indicators that the civil unrest will continue and be long enough and widespread enough to lead to regime change. 10% chance because things can always change. However, Russia seems intent on keeping the status quo on there border.
Seeming less likely, prsident has made live video addresses, Russia has made it clear they won't allow it to fail

The riots in Kazakhstan are ascribed different causes by different outlets, with some suggesting that they are motivated by persistent inequality and discontent with the government's economic policies and others framing the conflict as a coordinated response by allies of the former President Nazarbayev to Tokayev's attempts to remove them from positions of power. I think the likelihood that Tokayev flees the country is substantially influenced by which explanation is more salient, though I believe that both of these are likely partially valid explanations of the events in Kazahkstan. If the protests are organic and caused by economic discontent, then his ability to remain in-country will depend these issues will determine whether the situation is stabilized sufficiently. If the most violent riots were in fact coordinated and exacerbated by Tokayev's political rivals, I think it would be difficult to resolve the problem without concentrating power further under Tokayev, which could provoke increased resistance by the pro-democracy protestors. Structural reforms of the economy are also likely to be challenging and not swift enough to appease discontented citizens. I predict a small, but not insignificant probability of just under 10% that Tokayev flees. He is facing substantial challenges, but the fall of an autocratic leader in the post-soviet sphere might be viewed as problematic by other autocrats in the area, particularly Putin. I think it's very likely that Russian forces, perhaps under the auspices of the collective treaty security organization continue to conspire to support Tokayev and prevent his removal.

It isn't very likely that Tokayev will flee or cease to be Kazakhstan's president since the former president expressed support for him. Also, since there was just an attempted coup and Russia helped prevent the coup from succeeding, Tokayev will likely remain in power.

With the short time frame, backing from Russian troops that can deploy overnight, and no signs the political elites have turned on him; this seems pretty unlikely. More than a zero percent chance as there is recent precedent in the region of this happening

There is a whole number of factors that would indicate Tokayev's tenuous hold on power: invitation of foreign troops, albeit for a purely symbolic appearance, shoot-to-kill order, lack of founder's credibility of his predecessor, most probable opposition on the part of the dominating clans, China's taciturn bet on his rivals, complicity in the corruption, general status of a placeholder nominee. This said, his biggest advantage is that he is in power now and six months is a short time to execute a change in the succession game. His rivals need to time to get organized. This is why I give him 72% to be in his place in six months, and subsequently 28% to go.
Re-adjusted based on time horizon of July 2022
Russian “peacekeeping” forces seemed to have quelled any near-term exit possibilities due to civil unrest.
Down 15% following @indgra 's useful comments below.

I guess is Tokayev will stay in power. I have two primarily reasons to believe that. 1. Nursultan/Astana is a planned capital in the middle of nowhere. Would Almaty still be the seat of the important governmet institutions I would estimate the chance of the government toppling much higher. Almaty is the biggest population center in Kazakhstan, so a popular uprising there gives the government more time to quell any protests by bringing in forces from outside, while protesters in the capital have a much smaller pool of people to draw from a dissatisfied populace and would it would take more time for people to to arrive in Nursultan joining uprisings and protests. And furthermore, because it's a newly built city far away from anything, the people who move there are mostly government workers and contractors of all kind, in short living relatively well and secure and much less affected by the hardships of daily life in Kazakhstan, which led to the uprising in the first place. 2. Russian led foreign forces are already leaving as quickly as they have arrived, which I didn't expect so soon to be honest. But it shows that Tokayev can reliably count on rapidly deployed foreign reinforcement if needed as long he playes along with Russian interests and they wouldn't withdraw so quickly if Russia wouldn't be sure that Kazakh leadership is acting in their interest. So what could actually remove Tokayev from office? Well, the Russians are suddenly dissatisfied, but I think this is not very likely in the near future. He is overthrown within the government, but I assume as Tokayev has a long career in public service, I guess he knows quite well how the apparatus works. But I can't recollect something like that has happened in the post Soviet space so far. The most likely senario, I can imagine, that Russia will be militarily engaged in Ukraine and/or elsewhere, which is not unreasonable to assume at the moment and so thinly stretched in manpower that they can't intervene again that quickly, if the Kazakh people are rising up again especially when more widespread and in greater numbers. But again Kazahk authorities are now aware of puplic dissatifaction and won't be taken again by surprise. So my conclusion ist Tokayev will be president at 7 July 2022. Highly unlikely that he will out of power soon but not impossible, so I estimate generously 3% that he will be ousted. So what do you guys think of my thoughts? Where do you disagree, what did I miss? Thank you for your comments!
nice info about Tokayev. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/07/kassym-jomart-tokayev-veteran-kazakh-diplomat-faces-grave-crisis
Definitely some unresolved violence, but it doesn't seem to translate to regime instability at this point.

Underlying structural issues still exist as drivers of disruption and conflict, but Tokayev seems stable in his position due to the geographically limited scope of the protests, Russian support but quick withdrawal, and reframing the issue as an internal power struggle.
Highly unlikely that Kassym-Jomart Tokayev leaves or loses power. He will likely have sufficient support within the country to stay or find it outside the country.
Sputnik reports CSTO foreign ministers signed an agreement on withdrawal of peacekeeper (or “peacekeeper”—your choice of punctuation) forces.
with Russian support this is very unlikely

Tokayev will either be kept in power to signify continuity and stability (Carrie Lam style), or will be removed to mark a changing of the guard. I disagree with the consensus of many in this forum that Russia is calling all the shots in Kazakhstan, the internal power dynamic between the country's oligarchs is probably much more defining of what will occur. Tokayev is striking a balance between not ostracizing Nazarbayev and appearing as his "own man".
He is a dictator with Russian (putain ) backing

Tokayev actions will be fully at the direction/oversight of the Russian team ensconced to protect the interests of Russia. Accordingly, his self-directed behaviors will be limited for the near-term. He is essentially in a defacto house arrest until he can be replaced to the benefit of the Russian interests.
In my opinion, the real question is, will Putin permit it to happen? My guess is, No.

There is tension in between Tokayev and Nazarbayev and how that tension develops will be important. Nazarbayev still has an important place in the country but Tokayev has been recently acting independently of Nazarbayev, which the people would view positively. It is probably more beneficial to Nazarbayev to keep Tokayev in his circle since the people want "the old man out". If Tokayev can at least appear to be on the people's side while still keeping the trust of Nazarbayev, he'll probably stay as president for at least 6 months more.
definitely possible, given the instability (nearly 8,000 arrested in unrest)

Given Russia's focus on NATO and Ukraine at the moment, my initial thought is that they would not allow unrest in their neighbour to the south. The Russians have already proved willing to quickly squash rebellion. The Kazakhstan dictatorship is only 30 years old (established in 1991 and if Tokayev is viewed as a planted successor of Nazarbayev). Tokayev is only 68 so if he can maintain control his age is not a factor. Seems that the masses could be easily temporarily mollified with a lowering of LPG prices, at least over the question's time horizon. It does not seem that the protestors are strong enough to force an ouster by July 7, 2022. It's hard to imagine China wanting uncertainty in their neighbour as well.

The commitment of Russian and regional forces raises the stakes - the regime in Moscow has committed to keeping him in power and cannot risk a potentially hostile regime on their long southern border at a time of heightened tension with Ukraine. However, in the event that heavy western economic sanctions are imposed on Russia, Moscow's ability to maintain a large military presence in Kazakhstan (at the same time as continuing to threaten Ukraine, which is the higher priority) may be compromised.
Russian backing assures his position. Let's not forget his predecessor was in power for 30 years, so they don't change horses often.

I dont think Tokayev has a natural support base. the government has resigned which means he does not have overwhelming political support. He does not have the natural support of his predecessor as he has now criticised the old man. With 164 dead and foreign troops in the country I think his job is on a knife edge. His only hope is that putin wants stability but that is risky with russian troops in the country.
Going down to crowd. Russian troops are withdrawing, control has been regained, the coup has been quelled. The last few weeks will have made Tokayev's position stronger. Coming down to crowd

Odds are that he'll remain in power, but the Kazakh people are not sheep, and it may be that enough of them are tired enough of him that he is forced out somehow. Plus, he is not the youngest man in the world, so any further tension-- not necessarily violence-- may take a toll on his health.

The strongarm president has held power in the eyes of the protest and also shown that he can use CSTO if needed. As such he has enough support to quell most (if not all) immediate problems he might face. Plus the issue of the energy prices will be stabilized in the short term and mostly hold in the near medium term because of the summer lower use of power in general.

Tokayev has formed a new government. I’m not familiar with domestic politics in KZ, but reading Telegram comments, it seems many are “all familiar faces.” However, at least some key Nazarbayev people have been removed. There were also reports of deaths, including of a police chief in one of the hotspots (“undisclosed reasons”/suicide), one of the top security council officials (fell out of a window), and someone else in a similar post who had a heart attack.
I'm updating my forecast from 12% to 6% because my probability was based on the next 12 months and the question is a half year from now.
If the Russians end up shooting Kaszakh's its game over.

There's too much at stake for Russia and Putin to allow Tokayev to fall. The US needs a stable Kazakhastan after being booted out of Afghanistan. The Chinese influence is growing but not enough for them to be able to install someone.

I deny with 80 % the content of question. I assume that Russia’s military asymmetrical power is stronger than the power of unorganized opposition groups. Second the Head of Government is not reluctant to order immediately unlimited and deadly power by security forces on protesters. I assume: External help will have been not deployed by USA intelligence organizations like NSA, CIA, special forces: SEALS or Delta, etc.. due to situation of Russia Forces at Ukraine border. The risk of uncontrollable dynamics of several military conflicts are to high on “jugoslawia” of Eurasia. The economical win is negative for USA. In this area are the highest oil reserves of the planet as far as I know. Peace under given political circumstances ensures higher economical advantages for many of the most important players. The bad outcome of Afghanistan Occupation and the weaknesses of NATO is fresh in all minds after NATO Forces embarrassing retreat from Afghanistan some month ago.

- Has the backing of both Putin and Xi (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3162596/chinese-president-xi-jinping-sends-message-support-kazakhstans) - Seemed to weather the initial, surprise uprising - things have now settled. - The past President of Kazakhstan was in power for almost 29 years

My initial prediction is that there is a 88.4% chance Tokayev will still be president of Kazakhstan through July 7, 2022. I'm starting with the outside view. Here is my reasoning for how I arrived at my outside view:
Reducing probability of "Yes" by 5%.
No. He will remain President. the color revolution peaked too early.

Yes - Protester grievances remain unresolved (corruption, wealth inequality, direct local elections, high price of LNG) - Possibly less likely to reach a peaceful consensus w/ protesters now that widespread violence has been used and endorsed (pushes situation to extremes) - Lack of tools in Kazakh govt toolbox for resolving the situation without violence is limited (like 'kettling', will this exacerbate the situation?)
As @dowser mentioned, the rats are fleeing. I'm now slightly more inclined to think Tokayev will be forced to leave.

Current location of former president and ex-head of security council Nazarbayev remains unclear. There are rumors he’s in Germany or Dubai, but his press secretary claims he’s been in the capital all along (just happened not to be seen by anyone?). In addition to the ongoing removal of Nazarbayev’s people from key posts, there’s this statement claiming Nazarbayev “voluntarily” gave up his post as the security council head and passed it on to Tokayev: https://t.me/tengrinews/8808 (in Russian). What this tells me is Tokayev: 1 Nazarbayev: 0. Protestors are now all depicted as terrorists and foreign mercenaries. More than 5000 people have been detained. The media parades the names and photos of soldiers and police officers killed in the protests as well as images of ammunition captured from the “terrorists”. I’m keeping my probabilities relatively high due to the longish timeline and current level of uncertainty, but with the deployment of SCO (including Armenian troops), it would appear authoritarian leaders are now more skilled in suppressing popular uprisings and manipulating public opinion, which improves their chances of regime survival.
Putin has his back
He is consolidating his power and has russian support so his odds of staying in power for 6 more months are good. If the demonstrations and chaos continues or escalates I will up the odds.
Leaving some wiggle room as it's early days and the situation is fluid.
Russians support and fixed gas prices seem to be suppressing things for now.
Unlikely. Tokayev will use dictator tactics to solve the unrest before giving up power

If the situation with Ukraine remains unstable and riots break out again in other "near Russia" countries Putin may pull the plug on him. Above all Putin craves stability he has no loyalty to other dilators other than that.
Up 10%. Some rats reportedly leaving the ship:
Its unlikely because he has Russian backing
he is a dictator with Russian backing

Report that protests have died down on Saturday and streets of Almaty are quiet (at least for the time being): https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/01/08/kazakhstan-russia-protests-csto-tokayev/ Also reports that Karim Masimov, the former chairman of the National Security Committee, was detained on charges of treason. Masimov has been characterized as an ally to Nazarbayev, who has remained largely silent during the crisis: https://apnews.com/article/business-asia-arrests-kazakhstan-national-security-ea2b33fd9c8564b47361e9a29f82800f. Both of these events suggest Tokayev is keeping a firm grip on power and is more likely to win any internal power struggle that develops. Probability of a revolution or another elite coming to power should be lower now.

"The president is the holder of the highest office within the Republic of Kazakhstan. The powers of this position are described in a special section of the Constitution of Kazakhstan.The position was established on 24 April 1990, a year before the dissolution of the Soviet Union. The current president is Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, who assumed office on 20 March 2019 following the resignation of the first president, Nursultan Nazarbayev." [1]
Flee? Unlikely. Accidentally forget to not drink tea flavored with Polonium-204? Maybe. Tokayev is a despot, sure, but not one (yet?) in Putin's back pocket.

The crowd appears very confident. I disagree not with the direction but with the scale of that confidence. Dictatorships and authoritarian regimes are only stable until they are not. Thinking back to the 2005 Tulip Revolution in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan (different dynamics but still), I don’t think many people predicted President Akaev would flee the country so quickly. Now, Akaev didn’t order the military to shoot at unarmed protesters (one of the reasons why it’s a different story). President Bakiev, who came as a result of the Tulip Revolution, was ousted a little more than a year later. He did order the military to shoot. It didn’t save his presidency. More later about why this may not apply to wealthier Kazakhstan; the involvement of SCO; the way the media portray the events in KZ and neighbouring countries. What makes me less confident in a “no” outcome is the longish timeframe and the possibility Tokayev will get replaced after this crisis—as a “compromise” or some gesture from the Nazarbayevs, or as a result of clan power struggles if this continues, or as a result of possibly having an early election (although the timeline is short for that).

There are several reasons to think Tokayev will retain leadership position through July. He appears to have support from the Russian Federation; he has so far been able to exercise control over the security apparatus; and he has been able to sideline his predecessor, Nazarbayev. His recent announcement that security officials should "kill without warning" has been interpreted as a sign that he has been able to exercise control and that a successful suppression of the protests is more likely than it was a day ago. But Tokakev only rose to power recently, in 2019, after Nazarbayev finally stepped down after nearly 30 years as president. As a result, he likely hasn't had as much time to appoint loyalists to key leadership positions or to prove to the military that he can maintain stability. One report even stated that Tokayev was "once seen as nothing but an administrative appointee". After Nazarbayev's removal as head of the security council, there have been multiple reports of infighting among elites and rumors that members of Nazarbayev's loyalists and family members have been instigating some of the street violence. See: (1) https://www.ft.com/content/d6890bbc-5760-44fd-bdcf-dcdafc0fd058 and (2) https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/07/world/asia/kazakhstan-protests.html.
